.NET Guideline

.NET Developer Guideline

25 min read

The exhaustive reference for .NET development, clean code patterns, and project-specific conventions at AII.

Chapter 1

Project Overview

AII .NET applications are built using .NET 8.0/9.0 following Clean Architecture or Vertical Slice principles. Our goal is to maintain highly testable, independent, and scalable codebases.

.NET 8.0/9.0 ASP.NET Core
EF Core with PostgreSQL/SQL Server
MediatR for In-Process Messaging
FluentValidation for Logic
Mapster/AutoMapper for DTOs
Serilog & OpenTelemetry

New Developer Checklist

Follow these steps to get your first .NET project running at AII:

1

Install SDK

Download and install .NET 8.0 SDK and Runtime.

2

Setup IDE

Install JetBrains Rider (preferred) or VS 2022 with C# extensions.

3

Clone Template

Run 'dotnet new install AII.Templates' to get our latest skeleton.

4

Docker Setup

Ensure Docker Desktop is running for local PostgreSQL/Redis instances.

5

Run Tests

Execute 'dotnet test' to ensure the baseline project is stable.

Chapter 2

Architecture Design Choices

Clean Architecture (Layered)

Standard for enterprise-grade applications with complex domains.

csharpOrder.cs (Domain Layer)
public class Order : AggregateRoot
{
    public void MarkAsCompleted() {
        if (Status != OrderStatus.Processing)
            throw new DomainException("Invalid state transition");
        Status = OrderStatus.Completed;
    }
}
csharpCompleteOrderUseCase.cs (App Layer)
public async Task Execute(int orderId) {
    var order = await _orderRepository.GetByIdAsync(orderId);
    order.MarkAsCompleted();
    await _unitOfWork.SaveChangesAsync();
}

Layer Responsibilities

API Layer: Controllers, Endpoints, Middleware, Auth registration.

Application Layer: Commands, Queries, Handlers, DTOs, Validators.

Domain Layer: Entities, Value Objects, Domain Logic, Exceptions.

Infrastructure Layer: Data Access, External Clients, File Storage.

Chapter 3

Design Patterns

CQRS with MediatR

Separates read models from write models and enables decorators for logging and validation.

csharp
public record CreateStudentCommand(string Name) : IRequest<int>;
public class CreateStudentHandler : IRequestHandler<CreateStudentCommand, int> { ... }

Dependency Injection

Always use Constructor Injection. Prefer Scoped for DB context and Transient for lightweight services.

csharp
public class Service(IRepository repo) : IService {
    // Use Primary Constructor (C# 12)
}
Chapter 4

Data Access Patterns

Entity Framework Core

The primary ORM for AII .NET projects. Follow these best practices for performance.

✅ Eager Loading & NoTracking
csharp
var students = await _context.Students
    .AsNoTracking()
    .Include(s => s.Courses)
    .Where(s => s.IsActive)
    .ToListAsync();
Dapper for Performance

Use Dapper for high-performance read scenarios or complex stored procedures.

csharp
return await _dbConnection.QueryAsync<ReportDTO>(
    "EXEC GetComplexReport @Date", new { Date = DateTime.Now });
Chapter 5

API Implementation Approaches

Standard Controllers

Best for large-scale APIs requiring complex route attributes or filters.

csharp
[ApiController, Route("api/[controller]")]
public class StudentsController : ControllerBase {
    [HttpPost] public async Task<IActionResult> Create(DTO data) => Ok();
}

Minimal APIs

Recommended for microservices or simple feature sets. Less boilerplate.

csharp
app.MapPost("/api/students", async (Command cmd, ISender sender) => 
    Results.Ok(await sender.Send(cmd)));
Chapter 6

Naming Conventions

ElementConventionExample
Classes
PascalCase
UserService
Interfaces
IPascalCase
IUserRepository
Methods
PascalCaseAsync
GetListAsync
Fields (Private)
_camelCase
_logger
Parameters
camelCase
userId
Chapter 7

File and Project Organization

Clean Architecture Structure
src/
├── Application/      # UseCases, DTOs, Handlers
│   ├── Common/
│   ├── Interfaces/
│   └── TodoItems/    # Feature-based folders
├── Domain/           # Entities, Value Objects
├── Infrastructure/   # Persistence, External Systems
└── WebApi/           # Controllers, Middleware
Chapter 8

Validation & Error Handling

FluentValidation

Keep validation logic separate from your entities and commands.

csharp
public class CreateUserValidator : AbstractValidator<CreateUserCommand>
{
    public CreateUserValidator() {
        RuleFor(x => x.Email).NotEmpty().EmailAddress();
    }
}

Global Exception Handling

Use Exception Filters or Middleware to catch errors and return RFC-standard Problem Details.

Chapter 9

Testing Guidelines

Unit Testing (xUnit)

Test business logic in isolation using Moq or NSubstitute.

csharp
[Fact]
public async Task Handle_ValidRequest_ShouldReturnId() {
    // Arrange, Act, Assert
}

Integration Testing

Test the whole ASP.NET Core stack using WebApplicationFactory and Respawn.

Ready to Build?

Following these .NET standards ensures your application is robust, secure, and ready for production at AII.
